French PM Lecornu resigns hours after forming cabinet
subhead: The president's office announced that Sébastien Lecornu had tendered his resignation on Monday morning, hours after his new government had been announced.

title: Trump's Gaza plan puts Netanyahu in a bind
subhead: The Israeli prime minister is caught between pressure from the US president, who is determined to see his proposal through, and the intransigence of his far-right allies.

title: Pelicot rape case returns to court for lone appellant's trial
subhead: One year after the marathon trial that resulted in the conviction of 51 men for rape, attempted rape or sexual assault against Gisèle Pelicot, an appeals court is set to review the actions of Husamettin Dogan, age 44. In the first trial, he was sentenced to nine years in prison.

title: French museums continue to court American donors amid uncertainty
subhead: French cultural institutions fear that Donald Trump might abolish a tax deduction enjoyed by American 'friends of' associations.

title: Haoues Seniguer: 'The lack of a political solution in the Israel-Palestine conflict has benefited a brutalized form of religion'
subhead: The professor analyzes how certain politicized movements within Judaism and Islam have sanctified violence in the name of God, since the October 7 attacks perpetrated by Hamas and Israel's radical retaliation in Gaza.

Returning to Spain after generations of exile
subhead: The country is experiencing a sharp rise in population, driven by a wave of 'grandchildren' settling in the land of their ancestors who fled Francoist Spain, a place to which they feel attached, despite never having lived there.

title: Why foreigners love France but struggle with the French
subhead: While France captivates with its culture and lifestyle, the French, frequently caricatured as arrogant and impolite, often have a poor reputation. This ambivalence raises questions about the roots of anti-French sentiment abroad.

title: The West Bank village of Palestine's forgotten Americans
subhead: In the occupied West Bank, 85% of Turmus Ayya's population are American-Palestinian citizens. Every summer, these dual nationals return to visit their families and maintain ties with their homeland. They find that their American passports offer no immunity from persecution by the army and settlers in this territory, where illegal Israeli settlements are rapidly expanding.
